is an `(err ...)` response, `unwrap` returns the inner value of the `err`.
If the supplied argument is an `(ok ...)` value,
`unwrap-err` throws a runtime error, aborting any further processing of the current transaction.
functions.example:
(unwrap-err-panic (err 1)) ;; Returns 1
(unwrap-err-panic (ok 1)) ;; Throws a runtime exception

functions.name: unwrap-panic
functions.description:
The `unwrap` function attempts to 'unpack' its argument: if the argument is
an option type, and the argument is a `(some ...)` option, this function returns the inner value of the
option. If the argument is a response type, and the argument is an `(ok ...)` response, it returns
 the inner value of the `ok`. If the supplied argument is either an `(err ...)` or a `(none)` value,
`unwrap` throws a runtime error, aborting any further processing of the current transaction.
functions.example:
(define-map names-map { name: (string-ascii 12) } { id: int })
(map-set names-map { name: "blockstack" } { id: 1337 })
(unwrap-panic (map-get? names-map { name: "blockstack" })) ;; Returns (tuple (id 1337))
(unwrap-panic (map-get? names-map { name: "non-existant" })) ;; Throws a runtime exception

functions.name: use-trait
functions.description:
`use-trait` is used to bring a trait, defined in another contract, to the current contract. Subsequent
references to an imported trait are signaled with the syntax `<trait-alias>`.

Traits import are defined with a name, used as an alias, and a trait identifier. Trait identifiers can either be
using the sugared syntax (.token-a.token-trait), or be fully qualified ('SPAXYA5XS51713FDTQ8H94EJ4V579CXMTRNBZKSF.token-a.token-trait).

Like other kinds of definition statements, `use-trait` may only be used at the top level of a smart contract
definition (i.e., you cannot put such a statement in the middle of a function body).
functions.example:
(use-trait token-a-trait 'SPAXYA5XS51713FDTQ8H94EJ4V579CXMTRNBZKSF.token-a.token-trait)
(define-public (forward-get-balance (user principal) (contract <token-a-trait>))
  (begin
    (ok 1)))

functions.name: var-get
functions.description:
The `var-get` function looks up and returns an entry from a contract's data map.
The value is looked up using `var-name`.
functions.example:
(define-data-var cursor int 6)
(var-get cursor) ;; Returns 6

functions.name: var-set
functions.description:
The `var-set` function sets the value associated with the input variable to the
inputted value. The function always returns `true`.
functions.example:
(define-data-var cursor int 6)
(var-get cursor) ;; Returns 6
(var-set cursor (+ (var-get cursor) 1)) ;; Returns true
(var-get cursor) ;; Returns 7

functions.name: xor
functions.input_type: int, int | uint, uint | string-ascii, string-ascii | string-utf8, string-utf8 | buff, buff
functions.description: Returns the result of bitwise exclusive or'ing `i1` with `i2`.
functions.example:
(xor 1 2) ;; Returns 3
(xor 120 280) ;; Returns 352

keywords.name: contract-caller
keywords.description:
Returns the caller of the current contract context. If this contract is the first one called by a signed transaction,
the caller will be equal to the signing principal. If `contract-call?` was used to invoke a function from a new contract, `contract-caller`
changes to the _calling_ contract's principal. If `as-contract` is used to change the `tx-sender` context, `contract-caller` _also_ changes
to the same contract principal.
keywords.example: (print contract-caller) ;; Will print out a Stacks address of the transaction sender

keywords.name: tx-sender
keywords.description:
Returns the original sender of the current transaction, or if `as-contract` was called to modify the sending context, it returns that
contract principal.
keywords.example: (print tx-sender) ;; Will print out a Stacks address of the transaction sender

keywords.name: tx-sponsor?
keywords.description: Returns the sponsor of the current transaction if there is a sponsor, otherwise returns None.
keywords.example: (print tx-sponsor?) ;; Will print out an optional value containing the Stacks address of the transaction sponsor

keywords.name: block-height
keywords.description: Returns the current block height of the Stacks blockchain as an uint
keywords.example: (> block-height 1000) ;; returns true if the current block-height has passed 1000 blocks.

keywords.name: burn-block-height
keywords.description: Returns the current block height of the underlying burn blockchain as a uint
keywords.example: (> burn-block-height 1000) ;; returns true if the current height of the underlying burn blockchain has passed 1000 blocks.

keywords.name: chain-id
keywords.description: Returns the 32-bit chain ID of the blockchain running this transaction
keywords.example: (print chain-id) ;; Will print 'u1' if the code is running on mainnet, and 'u2147483648' on testnet, and other values on different chains.

keywords.name: is-in-mainnet
keywords.description: Returns a boolean indicating whether or not the code is running on the mainnet
keywords.example: (print is-in-mainnet) ;; Will print 'true' if the code is running on the mainnet

keywords.name: is-in-regtest
keywords.description: Returns whether or not the code is running in a regression test
keywords.example: (print is-in-regtest) ;; Will print 'true' if the code is running in a regression test

keywords.name: stx-liquid-supply
keywords.description: Returns the total number of micro-STX (uSTX) that are liquid in the system as of this block.
keywords.example: (print stx-liquid-supply) ;; Will print out the total number of liquid uSTX

keywords.name: false
keywords.example:
(and true false) ;; Evaluates to false
(or false true)  ;; Evaluates to true

keywords.name: none
keywords.description: Represents the _none_ option indicating no value for a given optional (analogous to a null value).
keywords.example:
(define-public (only-if-positive (a int))
  (if (> a 0)
      (some a)
      none))
(only-if-positive 4) ;; Returns (some 4)
(only-if-positive (- 3)) ;; Returns none

keywords.name: true
keywords.example:
(and true false) ;; Evaluates to false
(or false true)  ;; Evaluates to true
